column4: Something eats my disk space in Jackalope, I boot with 60Gb free space and I already have just 9Gb free, I am just editing text files and not using any large file, but it happens anyway... Why could this happen?
what does df -h show you?
df -h should show where the space is being used
It happens with /dev/sda2
where is /dev/sda2 mounted?
ok, just as a guess, do df -h /var
so some kind of logs can eat so much space?
yup, use natilus to go into the logs folder and see which one is getting big
or ls -l /var/log
/var/log is not using more than Mb, not Gb, so it doesnt seem to be the cause
/var/ is using 1.7 Gb
ok, use the same command ls -l /var and see if any large files show up there
still, 1.7gig is alot in /var unless you have a website running out of there
/var/ is  Ok
ok, well only guess is to start looking at individual directories then and see ... there is an app that will show you in a graph but I can't think of the name right now ... disk usage analysis maybe?
I read this: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?p=7991873 and now I think it may be that I created a symlink to another ntfs partition, could that be doing something wierd?
not sure, it could
I have 97% used... while chatting soon I will need to reboot, this is serious. Help me users
when you reboot the space frees up?
reboot and immediately open a terminal and run dmesg | tail and see if it gives any clues
